results.title: Quandong cake
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “People of the Australian western desert”.
A woman nurses her baby daughter, then prepares an uncooked cake made by crushing and mixing in water the dried skin and flesh of the quandong fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Old camp sites at Tika Tika
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Observation of everyday life continues, showing the women working at common tasks, mending a cracked wooden dish with spinifex gum and preparing a headache remedy from quandong seeds.

results.title: Mamu
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
A mamu is an evil spirit. Djungurai and Garimara are mapantjara, men who have the power to remove powerful bones and stones from their stomachs and use them for magic and medicine. Shows the men chasing away a papa, or dog spirit, by removing bones (mapampa) from their stomaches and hitting these along and into the ground with their spear-throwers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Making a wira
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Djunjurai locates a suitable tree from which to make a small wooden digging dish or wira. He starts on the tree trunk by using the hand chopper he had made, but after a time changes to a metal axe. The raw material for the dish is brought back to camp where he shapes it with an adze.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: A Family moves camp and gathers food
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Filmed in May 1965 in the Desert Sandhill country of the Western Desert, the film documents a group of Aboriginal families still living their traditional way of life. Shows them moving camp, hunting and gathering.

results.title: Women of the sun: 25 years later
results.creator_credit: Bob Weis, Julie Andrews and Generation Films
results.brief_description: The impact of the landmark 1981 Australian television drama series “Women of the Sun” on its audience was profound. Groundbreaking in its attempts to present stories of Aboriginal Australian women from their own perspectives and in their own languages, the series won the United Nations Media Peace Prize. In this moving documentary, Bob Weis - the producer of the series - explores the effects “Women of the Sun” has had on the lives of some of those involved with its making. Weis interviews some of the people who acted in the series - Justine Saunders, Shirley Nirrpurrangyydji, Naykalan Mununggur, Michelle LaCombe and Eva Johnson - as well as series co-writer Sonia Borg, and indigenous academic Marcia Langton. The film also features remarkable archival footage of series co-writer, poet and educator Hyllus Maris.

results.title: Knot at home project: disc two
results.creator_credit: Phillip Crawford, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission, BIG hART and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description: The eight films included in the two Knot at Home titles are the result of a series of community projects run by BIG hART, a non profit community organisation. The projects were designed to give people who often go unheard a chance to tell their stories. From 1998 to 2004 over five hundred young people were asked to tell stories about when they felt “not at home”. The “Knot at Home” films present their stories using interviews, narratives, vignettes, songs, animations, dramatised scenes and memories. The young storytellers have made the films themselves, mentored by experienced filmmakers. Contents of “Knot at Home Disc Two” are: Program Five, “Stories of my Family”; Program Six, “Stories of Loyalty” (short film sequences directed by Nathan Brown and Phillip Crawford); Program Seven, “Stories of Insight”; and Program Eight, “Stories About Telling my Story” (short film sequences directed by Rachel Ward). Disc One [319750].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phillip Crawford, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission, BIG hART and New South Wales Film and Television Office

results.title: Knot at home project: disc one
results.creator_credit: Phillip Crawford, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission, BIG hART and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description: The eight films included in the two Knot at Home titles are the result of a series of community projects run by BIG hART, a non profit community organisation. The projects were designed to give people who often go unheard a chance to tell their stories. From 1998 to 2004 over five hundred young people were asked to tell stories about when they felt “not at home”. The “Knot at Home” films present their stories using interviews, narratives, vignettes, songs, animations, dramatised scenes and memories. The young storytellers have made the films themselves, mentored by experienced filmmakers. Contents of “Knot at Home Disc One” are: Program One, “Stories of Survival” (short film sections directed by Sian Davies); Program Two, “Stories of Security” (short film section directed by Brendan Fletcher); Program Three, “Stories of Love”; (dramatised scenes directed by Bek Smith and Matt O’Connell) and Program Four, “Stories of Dreams” (short film sequences directed by Matthew Priestly and Bronwyn Purvis) Disc Two [319751].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phillip Crawford, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission, BIG hART and New South Wales Film and Television Office
